body:
Earlier today we posted [a big discussion thread](https://ruqq.us/5law) about the Yank mechanic. We had a lot of good discussion and ideas in that thread.

A lot of the underlying concerns fit into two categories: guildmaster abuse, and lack of communication.  Users were yanking content without regard to whether or not it fit, and Ruqqus itself did not notify users that their content had been yanked.

We've come up with a trial solution which we think will address these underlying concerns in a fair manner. We will try this for at least the next week, to see how well it works.

We've added a one hour cooldown on yanking. It works as follows:

* There is a one hour cooldown per-user
* There is also a one-hour cooldown per-guild
* Returning a post to its original guild (i.e. undoing a kick) ignores both cooldowns
* Yanking your own content also ignores both cooldowns.

Example: I am a guildmaster of +Ruqqus. I yank a random post from +general to +ruqqus. For one hour, I will be unable to yank anything to anywhere. For that same hour, no other guildmaster of +ruqqus will be able to yank content to +ruqqus either, but they will still be able to yank content to other guilds. 

With these cooldowns in place, we can also address the communication issue. We have added system notifications that are triggered by Yanking. We had left these out in the past since they could be used to spam with repeated kick-yank-kick-yank actions. Since that's no longer possible, we can add notifications without worrying about spam.

We hope that this addresses the underlying issues, while still allowing the Yank function to serve its original purpose of allowing unwanted content to find a new home.

As always, feedback is welcome below.

post.body:
Earlier today we posted [a big discussion thread](https://ruqq.us/5law) about the Yank mechanic. We had a lot of good discussion and ideas in that thread.

A lot of the underlying concerns fit into two categories: guildmaster abuse, and lack of communication.  Users were yanking content without regard to whether or not it fit, and Ruqqus itself did not notify users that their content had been yanked.

We've come up with a trial solution which we think will address these underlying concerns in a fair manner. We will try this for at least the next week, to see how well it works.

We've added a one hour cooldown on yanking. It works as follows:

* There is a one hour cooldown per-user
* There is also a one-hour cooldown per-guild
* Returning a post to its original guild (i.e. undoing a kick) ignores both cooldowns
* Yanking your own content also ignores both cooldowns.

Example: I am a guildmaster of +Ruqqus. I yank a random post from +general to +ruqqus. For one hour, I will be unable to yank anything to anywhere. For that same hour, no other guildmaster of +ruqqus will be able to yank content to +ruqqus either, but they will still be able to yank content to other guilds. 

With these cooldowns in place, we can also address the communication issue. We have added system notifications that are triggered by Yanking. We had left these out in the past since they could be used to spam with repeated kick-yank-kick-yank actions. Since that's no longer possible, we can add notifications without worrying about spam.

We hope that this addresses the underlying issues, while still allowing the Yank function to serve its original purpose of allowing unwanted content to find a new home.

As always, feedback is welcome below.

body:
That's not the solution we opted for...

We chose for users to have the ability to toggle whether or not they want their post to be yankable and the option to make posts unyankable to blocked guilds.

Earlier today we posted a big discussion thread about the Yank mechanic. We had a lot of good discussion and ideas in that thread.

A lot of the underlying concerns fit into two categories: guildmaster abuse, and lack of communication. Users were yanking content without regard to whether or not it fit, and Ruqqus itself did not notify users that their content had been yanked.

We've come up with a trial solution which we think will address these underlying concerns in a fair manner. We will try this for at least the next week, to see how well it works.

We've added a one hour cooldown on yanking. It works as follows:

  • There is a one hour cooldown per-user
  • There is also a one-hour cooldown per-guild
  • Returning a post to its original guild (i.e. undoing a kick) ignores both cooldowns
  • Yanking your own content also ignores both cooldowns.

Example: I am a guildmaster of +Ruqqus. I yank a random post from +general to +Ruqqus. For one hour, I will be unable to yank anything to anywhere. For that same hour, no other guildmaster of +Ruqqus will be able to yank content to +Ruqqus either, but they will still be able to yank content to other guilds.

With these cooldowns in place, we can also address the communication issue. We have added system notifications that are triggered by Yanking. We had left these out in the past since they could be used to spam with repeated kick-yank-kick-yank actions. Since that's no longer possible, we can add notifications without worrying about spam.

We hope that this addresses the underlying issues, while still allowing the Yank function to serve its original purpose of allowing unwanted content to find a new home.

As always, feedback is welcome below.

post.body:
Earlier today we posted [a big discussion thread](https://ruqq.us/5law) about the Yank mechanic. We had a lot of good discussion and ideas in that thread.

A lot of the underlying concerns fit into two categories: guildmaster abuse, and lack of communication.  Users were yanking content without regard to whether or not it fit, and Ruqqus itself did not notify users that their content had been yanked.

We've come up with a trial solution which we think will address these underlying concerns in a fair manner. We will try this for at least the next week, to see how well it works.

We've added a one hour cooldown on yanking. It works as follows:

* There is a one hour cooldown per-user
* There is also a one-hour cooldown per-guild
* Returning a post to its original guild (i.e. undoing a kick) ignores both cooldowns
* Yanking your own content also ignores both cooldowns.

Example: I am a guildmaster of +Ruqqus. I yank a random post from +general to +ruqqus. For one hour, I will be unable to yank anything to anywhere. For that same hour, no other guildmaster of +ruqqus will be able to yank content to +ruqqus either, but they will still be able to yank content to other guilds. 

With these cooldowns in place, we can also address the communication issue. We have added system notifications that are triggered by Yanking. We had left these out in the past since they could be used to spam with repeated kick-yank-kick-yank actions. Since that's no longer possible, we can add notifications without worrying about spam.

We hope that this addresses the underlying issues, while still allowing the Yank function to serve its original purpose of allowing unwanted content to find a new home.

As always, feedback is welcome below.

body:
1 hour cool down is pretty long as we grow, there will be more posts and theoretically only one guild that is relevant to that subject. A cool down makes it more difficult for me to prevent posts I would have yanked properly to go to troll guilds. It means one has to be pickier. And really people should just post to the right guild. I guess this is still useful for new people who don’t know what guilds there are. But imo a cooldown mostly doesn’t help that much, it “helps” as much as it hurts good faith users. 

But most importantly, post that has been kicked from a guild the user should be to move to a new guild they want to help get it to the right place, as when I kick I often say this content is more suitable to x guild and you should direct your content there.

I guess this is still useful for new people who don’t know what guilds there are. But imo a cooldown mostly doesn’t help that much, it “helps” as much as it hurts good faith users.

But most importantly, post that has been kicked from a guild the user should be to move to a new guild they want to help get it to the right place, as when I kick I often say this content is more suitable to x guild and you should direct your content there.

post.body:
Earlier today we posted [a big discussion thread](https://ruqq.us/5law) about the Yank mechanic. We had a lot of good discussion and ideas in that thread.

A lot of the underlying concerns fit into two categories: guildmaster abuse, and lack of communication.  Users were yanking content without regard to whether or not it fit, and Ruqqus itself did not notify users that their content had been yanked.

We've come up with a trial solution which we think will address these underlying concerns in a fair manner. We will try this for at least the next week, to see how well it works.

We've added a one hour cooldown on yanking. It works as follows:

* There is a one hour cooldown per-user
* There is also a one-hour cooldown per-guild
* Returning a post to its original guild (i.e. undoing a kick) ignores both cooldowns
* Yanking your own content also ignores both cooldowns.

Example: I am a guildmaster of +Ruqqus. I yank a random post from +general to +ruqqus. For one hour, I will be unable to yank anything to anywhere. For that same hour, no other guildmaster of +ruqqus will be able to yank content to +ruqqus either, but they will still be able to yank content to other guilds. 

With these cooldowns in place, we can also address the communication issue. We have added system notifications that are triggered by Yanking. We had left these out in the past since they could be used to spam with repeated kick-yank-kick-yank actions. Since that's no longer possible, we can add notifications without worrying about spam.

We hope that this addresses the underlying issues, while still allowing the Yank function to serve its original purpose of allowing unwanted content to find a new home.

As always, feedback is welcome below.

parent.body:
1 hour cool down is pretty long as we grow, there will be more posts and theoretically only one guild that is relevant to that subject. A cool down makes it more difficult for me to prevent posts I would have yanked properly to go to troll guilds. It means one has to be pickier. And really people should just post to the right guild. I guess this is still useful for new people who don’t know what guilds there are. But imo a cooldown mostly doesn’t help that much, it “helps” as much as it hurts good faith users. 

But most importantly, post that has been kicked from a guild the user should be to move to a new guild they want to help get it to the right place, as when I kick I often say this content is more suitable to x guild and you should direct your content there.

body:
>Yanking your own content also ignores both cooldowns.

Does that suggest I can yank my own post mistakenly put in +General to ANY guild from which I'm not blocked (since I could just delete and repost it there, but people are lazy) - or simply if I happen to be yanking it to a guild I control which seems very unlikely since if I control the guild I probably very clearly post it there :P

body:
Maybe that would help. I’m not sure this is the best solution though. 

At the moment there isn’t any way to penalize a user for wrongfully yanking. 

What if a user removes their post back to general after it’s yanked because they didn’t like the yank, the user loses an amount of rep? Or what if there was a post-yank rating system? And low ratings reduce yank privileges etc? Just some other ideas...
body_html:
Maybe that would help. I’m not sure this is the best solution though.

At the moment there isn’t any way to penalize a user for wrongfully yanking.

What if a user removes their post back to general after it’s yanked because they didn’t like the yank, the user loses an amount of rep? Or what if there was a post-yank rating system? And low ratings reduce yank privileges etc? Just some other ideas...

post.body:
Earlier today we posted [a big discussion thread](https://ruqq.us/5law) about the Yank mechanic. We had a lot of good discussion and ideas in that thread.

A lot of the underlying concerns fit into two categories: guildmaster abuse, and lack of communication.  Users were yanking content without regard to whether or not it fit, and Ruqqus itself did not notify users that their content had been yanked.

We've come up with a trial solution which we think will address these underlying concerns in a fair manner. We will try this for at least the next week, to see how well it works.

We've added a one hour cooldown on yanking. It works as follows:

* There is a one hour cooldown per-user
* There is also a one-hour cooldown per-guild
* Returning a post to its original guild (i.e. undoing a kick) ignores both cooldowns
* Yanking your own content also ignores both cooldowns.

Example: I am a guildmaster of +Ruqqus. I yank a random post from +general to +ruqqus. For one hour, I will be unable to yank anything to anywhere. For that same hour, no other guildmaster of +ruqqus will be able to yank content to +ruqqus either, but they will still be able to yank content to other guilds. 

With these cooldowns in place, we can also address the communication issue. We have added system notifications that are triggered by Yanking. We had left these out in the past since they could be used to spam with repeated kick-yank-kick-yank actions. Since that's no longer possible, we can add notifications without worrying about spam.

We hope that this addresses the underlying issues, while still allowing the Yank function to serve its original purpose of allowing unwanted content to find a new home.

As always, feedback is welcome below.

That's not the solution we opted for...

We chose for users to have the ability to toggle whether or not they want their post to be yankable and the option to make posts unyankable to blocked guilds.

body:
Can I ask for your stance on this? Why is this problem nonexistent when it's causing trouble for a lot of users? Clearly, they think that they would benefit from at least letting their own posts not get yanked, and I don't see what the downside is other than that it provides less of an incentive to post to more relevant guilds (In my view, +general's secondary purpose is to serve as a backup guild for if you get banned from other guilds). I can see how it's "fair game" if you posted directly in +general, but  if your post got kicked even when it was on-topic (let's say because of guildmaster abuse or an unexpected change in the mod team), why is it "fair game" to let everyone else yank it into all their different containment guilds?

<sup> - sfrohne [If you're going to post a screenshot of this comment, **don't** censor my username]</sup>
body_html:
Can I ask for your stance on this? Why is this problem nonexistent when it's causing trouble for a lot of users? I can see how it's "fair game" if you posted directly in +general, but if your post got kicked even when it was on-topic (let's say because of guildmaster abuse or an unexpected change in the mod team), why is it "fair game" to let everyone else yank it into all their different containment guilds?

- sfrohne [If you're going to post a screenshot of this comment, don't censor my username]

post.body:
Earlier today we posted [a big discussion thread](https://ruqq.us/5law) about the Yank mechanic. We had a lot of good discussion and ideas in that thread.

A lot of the underlying concerns fit into two categories: guildmaster abuse, and lack of communication.  Users were yanking content without regard to whether or not it fit, and Ruqqus itself did not notify users that their content had been yanked.

We've come up with a trial solution which we think will address these underlying concerns in a fair manner. We will try this for at least the next week, to see how well it works.

We've added a one hour cooldown on yanking. It works as follows:

* There is a one hour cooldown per-user
* There is also a one-hour cooldown per-guild
* Returning a post to its original guild (i.e. undoing a kick) ignores both cooldowns
* Yanking your own content also ignores both cooldowns.

Example: I am a guildmaster of +Ruqqus. I yank a random post from +general to +ruqqus. For one hour, I will be unable to yank anything to anywhere. For that same hour, no other guildmaster of +ruqqus will be able to yank content to +ruqqus either, but they will still be able to yank content to other guilds. 

With these cooldowns in place, we can also address the communication issue. We have added system notifications that are triggered by Yanking. We had left these out in the past since they could be used to spam with repeated kick-yank-kick-yank actions. Since that's no longer possible, we can add notifications without worrying about spam.

We hope that this addresses the underlying issues, while still allowing the Yank function to serve its original purpose of allowing unwanted content to find a new home.

As always, feedback is welcome below.

For that same hour, no other guildmaster of +Ruqqus will be able to yank content to +Ruqqus either, but they will still be able to yank content to other guilds.

With these cooldowns in place, we can also address the communication issue. We have added system notifications that are triggered by Yanking. We had left these out in the past since they could be used to spam with repeated kick-yank-kick-yank actions. Since that's no longer possible, we can add notifications without worrying about spam.

We hope that this addresses the underlying issues, while still allowing the Yank function to serve its original purpose of allowing unwanted content to find a new home.

As always, feedback is welcome below.
post.title: Ruqqus balance patch 2.26.6 - Yanking nerf

body:
This is a pretty bad solution imo unless it's a temporary fix. Having a 1 hour CD shared among GMs completely defeats the purpose of pulling relevant content into your guild. Are you supposed to coordinate with the other GMs in case they see a post at the same time? What if there are two relevant posts in +general, you just have to choose one? And it seems like a horrible user experience as a GM to hunt around +general for a while to find a post worthy of yanking only to find out your guild's yank is on cooldown because some other GM just recently yanked a different post. If you're going to leave this in place you might as well just remove yanking entirely and disallow posting in +general completely.

The #4 solution from the other thread was way more popular and makes more sense. It keeps the choice with the individual. In my opinion it also needs a condition where posts made directly to +general can't have yanking turned off. It should only be toggleable if your post has been kicked from a guild at least once.

It also needs to be way more clear when posting in +general that +general is not a guild you're meant to post directly to unless you want to risk having your post yanked. Otherwise as someone else pointed out in this thread, it's basically just a higher visibility feed for your content. 

The goal should be for users to **not** want to post in +general if their content is relevant to a specific guild. This change does the opposite, you've nerfed yanking and inadvertently buffed +general as a result. Why would I even bother posting in a specific guild now? I can get more visibility in +general and yanking basically doesn't exist anymore.

post.body:
Earlier today we posted [a big discussion thread](https://ruqq.us/5law) about the Yank mechanic. We had a lot of good discussion and ideas in that thread.

A lot of the underlying concerns fit into two categories: guildmaster abuse, and lack of communication.  Users were yanking content without regard to whether or not it fit, and Ruqqus itself did not notify users that their content had been yanked.

We've come up with a trial solution which we think will address these underlying concerns in a fair manner. We will try this for at least the next week, to see how well it works.

We've added a one hour cooldown on yanking. It works as follows:

* There is a one hour cooldown per-user
* There is also a one-hour cooldown per-guild
* Returning a post to its original guild (i.e. undoing a kick) ignores both cooldowns
* Yanking your own content also ignores both cooldowns.

Example: I am a guildmaster of +Ruqqus. I yank a random post from +general to +ruqqus. For one hour, I will be unable to yank anything to anywhere. For that same hour, no other guildmaster of +ruqqus will be able to yank content to +ruqqus either, but they will still be able to yank content to other guilds. 

With these cooldowns in place, we can also address the communication issue. We have added system notifications that are triggered by Yanking. We had left these out in the past since they could be used to spam with repeated kick-yank-kick-yank actions. Since that's no longer possible, we can add notifications without worrying about spam.

We hope that this addresses the underlying issues, while still allowing the Yank function to serve its original purpose of allowing unwanted content to find a new home.

As always, feedback is welcome below.

post.title: Ruqqus balance patch 2.26.6 - Yanking nerf

body:
This will greatly lessen the abuse, but it doesn't solve the underlying problem. The main problem is that yanking gives GMs to much power over other users' posts. 

A GM should only have power over the guild, and the ability to kick posts out. But allowing them to yank posts from +general enables them to exert influence on posts OUTSIDE of their guild.

Instead, users should just be given sovereignty over their own posts. If my post gets kicked to general, I should be the one to decide what other guild to move it to, as long as I am not exiled from that guild and the post hasn't already been kicked from there.
body_html:
This will greatly lessen the abuse, but it doesn't solve the underlying problem. The main problem is that yanking gives GMs to much power over other users' posts.

A GM should only have power over the guild, and the ability to kick posts out. But allowing them to yank posts from +general enables them to exert influence on posts OUTSIDE of their guild.

Instead, users should just be given sovereignty over their own posts. If my post gets kicked to general, I should be the one to decide what other guild to move it to, as long as I am not exiled from that guild and the post hasn't already been kicked from there.

parent.body:
Can I ask for your stance on this? Why is this problem nonexistent when it's causing trouble for a lot of users? Clearly, they think that they would benefit from at least letting their own posts not get yanked, and I don't see what the downside is other than that it provides less of an incentive to post to more relevant guilds (In my view, +general's secondary purpose is to serve as a backup guild for if you get banned from other guilds). I can see how it's "fair game" if you posted directly in +general, but  if your post got kicked even when it was on-topic (let's say because of guildmaster abuse or an unexpected change in the mod team), why is it "fair game" to let everyone else yank it into all their different containment guilds?

<sup> - sfrohne [If you're going to post a screenshot of this comment, **don't** censor my username]</sup>

body:
This seems like a duct tape fix.

The opt-in feature was unequivocally the most-voted solution. Now, I am certain that this will *aid* resolving the issue, but having a switch:

On/Off

Would certainly *solve* it. That's just my tuppence opinion, though :/

body: Why aren't posts simply COPIED? If someone posts something in the main area and a guild master thinks it would be a good fit for their guild, why can't the post simply be copied? Is there some kind of conservation of postings law at work which say that once created a post can never be destroyed, only moved around?
body_html:
Why aren't posts simply COPIED?

If someone posts something in the main area and a guild master thinks it would be a good fit for their guild, why can't the post simply be copied?

Is there some kind of conservation of postings law at work which say that once created a post can never be destroyed, only moved around?

author.ban_reason: Permanent ban for offering CP to a minor

body:
> discussion

While I was asleep lol.

I, along with @madje, think it's a good idea to have a toggle instead. So, if you have a post that's being downvoted in +general, you could yank it to a place t fits. But, if you already yanked it, there are two outcomes. If you are the sole GM, then you can't yank anymore. If you're not, there's no built-in way to contact the other GMs asking them to yank it.

Oh and, 

The users that yank for no reason **will just use alts**
--
body_html:
discussion

While I was asleep lol.

I, along with @Madje, think it's a good idea to have a toggle instead. So, if you have a post that's being downvoted in +general, you could yank it to a place t fits. But, if you already yanked it, there are two outcomes. If you are the sole GM, then you can't yank anymore. If you're not, there's no built-in way to contact the other GMs asking them to yank it.

Oh and,

The users that yank for no reason will just use alts

post.body:
Earlier today we posted [a big discussion thread](https://ruqq.us/5law) about the Yank mechanic. We had a lot of good discussion and ideas in that thread.

A lot of the underlying concerns fit into two categories: guildmaster abuse, and lack of communication.  Users were yanking content without regard to whether or not it fit, and Ruqqus itself did not notify users that their content had been yanked.

We've come up with a trial solution which we think will address these underlying concerns in a fair manner. We will try this for at least the next week, to see how well it works.

We've added a one hour cooldown on yanking. It works as follows:

* There is a one hour cooldown per-user
* There is also a one-hour cooldown per-guild
* Returning a post to its original guild (i.e. undoing a kick) ignores both cooldowns
* Yanking your own content also ignores both cooldowns.

Example: I am a guildmaster of +Ruqqus. I yank a random post from +general to +ruqqus. For one hour, I will be unable to yank anything to anywhere. For that same hour, no other guildmaster of +ruqqus will be able to yank content to +ruqqus either, but they will still be able to yank content to other guilds. 

With these cooldowns in place, we can also address the communication issue. We have added system notifications that are triggered by Yanking. We had left these out in the past since they could be used to spam with repeated kick-yank-kick-yank actions. Since that's no longer possible, we can add notifications without worrying about spam.

We hope that this addresses the underlying issues, while still allowing the Yank function to serve its original purpose of allowing unwanted content to find a new home.

As always, feedback is welcome below.

body:
From +general? No, that would just clog general with unyanked items.

If OP kicks their post to +general from a guild it was yanked to it should have a lock on it preventing it from being yanked back top that guild, but THEN a request to yank could be made and would need OP's approval to yank it back to a guild that OP kicked it from.
body_html:
From +general? No, that would just clog general with unyanked items.

If OP kicks their post to +general from a guild it was yanked to it should have a lock on it preventing it from being yanked back top that guild, but THEN a request to yank could be made and would need OP's approval to yank it back to a guild that OP kicked it from.

post.body:
Earlier today we posted [a big discussion thread](https://ruqq.us/5law) about the Yank mechanic. We had a lot of good discussion and ideas in that thread.

A lot of the underlying concerns fit into two categories: guildmaster abuse, and lack of communication.  Users were yanking content without regard to whether or not it fit, and Ruqqus itself did not notify users that their content had been yanked.

We've come up with a trial solution which we think will address these underlying concerns in a fair manner. We will try this for at least the next week, to see how well it works.

We've added a one hour cooldown on yanking. It works as follows:

* There is a one hour cooldown per-user
* There is also a one-hour cooldown per-guild
* Returning a post to its original guild (i.e. undoing a kick) ignores both cooldowns
* Yanking your own content also ignores both cooldowns.

Example: I am a guildmaster of +Ruqqus. I yank a random post from +general to +ruqqus. For one hour, I will be unable to yank anything to anywhere. For that same hour, no other guildmaster of +ruqqus will be able to yank content to +ruqqus either, but they will still be able to yank content to other guilds. 

With these cooldowns in place, we can also address the communication issue. We have added system notifications that are triggered by Yanking. We had left these out in the past since they could be used to spam with repeated kick-yank-kick-yank actions. Since that's no longer possible, we can add notifications without worrying about spam.

We hope that this addresses the underlying issues, while still allowing the Yank function to serve its original purpose of allowing unwanted content to find a new home.

As always, feedback is welcome below.

This seems like a duct tape fix.

The opt-in feature was unequivocally the most-voted solution. Now, I am certain that this will *aid* resolving the issue, but having a switch:

On/Off

Would certainly *solve* it. That's just my tuppence opinion, though :/

parent.body:
> discussion

While I was asleep lol.

I, along with @madje, think it's a good idea to have a toggle instead. So, if you have a post that's being downvoted in +general, you could yank it to a place t fits. But, if you already yanked it, there are two outcomes. If you are the sole GM, then you can't yank anymore. If you're not, there's no built-in way to contact the other GMs asking them to yank it.

Oh and, 

The users that yank for no reason **will just use alts**
--

post.body:
Earlier today we posted [a big discussion thread](https://ruqq.us/5law) about the Yank mechanic. We had a lot of good discussion and ideas in that thread.

A lot of the underlying concerns fit into two categories: guildmaster abuse, and lack of communication.  Users were yanking content without regard to whether or not it fit, and Ruqqus itself did not notify users that their content had been yanked.

We've come up with a trial solution which we think will address these underlying concerns in a fair manner. We will try this for at least the next week, to see how well it works.

We've added a one hour cooldown on yanking. It works as follows:

* There is a one hour cooldown per-user
* There is also a one-hour cooldown per-guild
* Returning a post to its original guild (i.e. undoing a kick) ignores both cooldowns
* Yanking your own content also ignores both cooldowns.

Example: I am a guildmaster of +Ruqqus. I yank a random post from +general to +ruqqus. For one hour, I will be unable to yank anything to anywhere. For that same hour, no other guildmaster of +ruqqus will be able to yank content to +ruqqus either, but they will still be able to yank content to other guilds. 

With these cooldowns in place, we can also address the communication issue. We have added system notifications that are triggered by Yanking. We had left these out in the past since they could be used to spam with repeated kick-yank-kick-yank actions. Since that's no longer possible, we can add notifications without worrying about spam.

We hope that this addresses the underlying issues, while still allowing the Yank function to serve its original purpose of allowing unwanted content to find a new home.

As always, feedback is welcome below.

  • There is a one hour cooldown per-user
  • There is also a one-hour cooldown per-guild
  • Returning a post to its original guild (i.e. undoing a kick) ignores both cooldowns
  • Yanking your own content also ignores both cooldowns.

Example: I am a guildmaster of +Ruqqus. I yank a random post from +general to +Ruqqus. For one hour, I will be unable to yank anything to anywhere. parent.body:
This will greatly lessen the abuse, but it doesn't solve the underlying problem. The main problem is that yanking gives GMs to much power over other users' posts. 

A GM should only have power over the guild, and the ability to kick posts out. But allowing them to yank posts from +general enables them to exert influence on posts OUTSIDE of their guild.

Instead, users should just be given sovereignty over their own posts. If my post gets kicked to general, I should be the one to decide what other guild to move it to, as long as I am not exiled from that guild and the post hasn't already been kicked from there.
parent.body_html:
This will greatly lessen the abuse, but it doesn't solve the underlying problem. The main problem is that yanking gives GMs to much power over other users' posts.

A GM should only have power over the guild, and the ability to kick posts out. But allowing them to yank posts from +general enables them to exert influence on posts OUTSIDE of their guild.

Instead, users should just be given sovereignty over their own posts. If my post gets kicked to general, I should be the one to decide what other guild to move it to, as long as I am not exiled from that guild and the post hasn't already been kicked from there.

post.body:
Earlier today we posted [a big discussion thread](https://ruqq.us/5law) about the Yank mechanic. We had a lot of good discussion and ideas in that thread.

A lot of the underlying concerns fit into two categories: guildmaster abuse, and lack of communication.  Users were yanking content without regard to whether or not it fit, and Ruqqus itself did not notify users that their content had been yanked.

We've come up with a trial solution which we think will address these underlying concerns in a fair manner. We will try this for at least the next week, to see how well it works.

We've added a one hour cooldown on yanking. It works as follows:

* There is a one hour cooldown per-user
* There is also a one-hour cooldown per-guild
* Returning a post to its original guild (i.e. undoing a kick) ignores both cooldowns
* Yanking your own content also ignores both cooldowns.

Example: I am a guildmaster of +Ruqqus. I yank a random post from +general to +ruqqus. For one hour, I will be unable to yank anything to anywhere. For that same hour, no other guildmaster of +ruqqus will be able to yank content to +ruqqus either, but they will still be able to yank content to other guilds. 

With these cooldowns in place, we can also address the communication issue. We have added system notifications that are triggered by Yanking. We had left these out in the past since they could be used to spam with repeated kick-yank-kick-yank actions. Since that's no longer possible, we can add notifications without worrying about spam.

We hope that this addresses the underlying issues, while still allowing the Yank function to serve its original purpose of allowing unwanted content to find a new home.

As always, feedback is welcome below.

body: It's also worth remembering that the 'best' solution is not necessarily whatever is the most popular. It's the arguments that matter, not votes. Indeed, option 4's flaw was that defaulting to opt-in fails to solve the core problem, and defaulting to opt-out effectively disables Yanking for the vast majority of users and kills the feature.
body_html: It's also worth remembering that the 'best' solution is not necessarily whatever is the most popular. It's the arguments that matter, not votes. Indeed, option 4's flaw was that defaulting to opt-in fails to solve the core problem, and defaulting to opt-out effectively disables Yanking for the vast majority of users and kills the feature.

body:
There are two types of posts that can be yanked for free without worrying about cooldowns. These also don't trigger notifications. 

1. Your own content
2. Content that was posted in a guild, kicked to general, and is now being yanked back to that same guild. 

Every other yank has the cooldown and a notification.

>Yanking your own content also ignores both cooldowns.

Does that suggest I can yank my own post mistakenly put in +General to ANY guild from which I'm not blocked (since I could just delete and repost it there, but people are lazy) - or simply if I happen to be yanking it to a guild I control which seems very unlikely since if I control the guild I probably very clearly post it there :P

post.body:
Earlier today we posted [a big discussion thread](https://ruqq.us/5law) about the Yank mechanic. We had a lot of good discussion and ideas in that thread.

A lot of the underlying concerns fit into two categories: guildmaster abuse, and lack of communication.  Users were yanking content without regard to whether or not it fit, and Ruqqus itself did not notify users that their content had been yanked.

We've come up with a trial solution which we think will address these underlying concerns in a fair manner. We will try this for at least the next week, to see how well it works.

We've added a one hour cooldown on yanking. It works as follows:

* There is a one hour cooldown per-user
* There is also a one-hour cooldown per-guild
* Returning a post to its original guild (i.e. undoing a kick) ignores both cooldowns
* Yanking your own content also ignores both cooldowns.

Example: I am a guildmaster of +Ruqqus. I yank a random post from +general to +ruqqus. For one hour, I will be unable to yank anything to anywhere. For that same hour, no other guildmaster of +ruqqus will be able to yank content to +ruqqus either, but they will still be able to yank content to other guilds. 

With these cooldowns in place, we can also address the communication issue. We have added system notifications that are triggered by Yanking. We had left these out in the past since they could be used to spam with repeated kick-yank-kick-yank actions. Since that's no longer possible, we can add notifications without worrying about spam.

We hope that this addresses the underlying issues, while still allowing the Yank function to serve its original purpose of allowing unwanted content to find a new home.

As always, feedback is welcome below.

parent.body: It's also worth remembering that the 'best' solution is not necessarily whatever is the most popular. It's the arguments that matter, not votes. Indeed, option 4's flaw was that defaulting to opt-in fails to solve the core problem, and defaulting to opt-out effectively disables Yanking for the vast majority of users and kills the feature.

body:
Hmm, I would suggest next time to let the discussion happen in all timezones, not only few chosen ones (I am guessing US?). If I am reading it correctly, those two posts about yanking are 10h from each other (+ you had to implement it, so even fewer hours of discussion was taken into account). Unless Ruqqus is meant to be few-timezones-only, you have to give the discussion at least 1 whole day to allow all who are interested in the topic to respond.

I would personally prefer the pre-rejected option: "make the user agree to a yank before it's completed". A user should have the most control, since it's his post in +general and he can be easily trolled or borderline censored by malicious GM(s). This option could be improved further: a user could have pre-approved GMs and/or guilds by/to which posts can be yanked instantly (yank automatically approved).

Last point, don't ask community for their opinion, if you are planning on ignoring them. Number 4 - "Allow users to toggle the ability to yank their posts" clearly won (two most upvoted comments), yet wasn't implemented? 🤨

post.body:
Earlier today we posted [a big discussion thread](https://ruqq.us/5law) about the Yank mechanic. We had a lot of good discussion and ideas in that thread.

A lot of the underlying concerns fit into two categories: guildmaster abuse, and lack of communication.  Users were yanking content without regard to whether or not it fit, and Ruqqus itself did not notify users that their content had been yanked.

We've come up with a trial solution which we think will address these underlying concerns in a fair manner. We will try this for at least the next week, to see how well it works.

We've added a one hour cooldown on yanking. It works as follows:

* There is a one hour cooldown per-user
* There is also a one-hour cooldown per-guild
* Returning a post to its original guild (i.e. undoing a kick) ignores both cooldowns
* Yanking your own content also ignores both cooldowns.

Example: I am a guildmaster of +Ruqqus. I yank a random post from +general to +ruqqus. For one hour, I will be unable to yank anything to anywhere. For that same hour, no other guildmaster of +ruqqus will be able to yank content to +ruqqus either, but they will still be able to yank content to other guilds. 

With these cooldowns in place, we can also address the communication issue. We have added system notifications that are triggered by Yanking. We had left these out in the past since they could be used to spam with repeated kick-yank-kick-yank actions. Since that's no longer possible, we can add notifications without worrying about spam.

We hope that this addresses the underlying issues, while still allowing the Yank function to serve its original purpose of allowing unwanted content to find a new home.

As always, feedback is welcome below.

parent.body:
Hmm, I would suggest next time to let the discussion happen in all timezones, not only few chosen ones (I am guessing US?). If I am reading it correctly, those two posts about yanking are 10h from each other (+ you had to implement it, so even fewer hours of discussion was taken into account). Unless Ruqqus is meant to be few-timezones-only, you have to give the discussion at least 1 whole day to allow all who are interested in the topic to respond.

I would personally prefer the pre-rejected option: "make the user agree to a yank before it's completed". A user should have the most control, since it's his post in +general and he can be easily trolled or borderline censored by malicious GM(s). This option could be improved further: a user could have pre-approved GMs and/or guilds by/to which posts can be yanked instantly (yank automatically approved).

Last point, don't ask community for their opinion, if you are planning on ignoring them. Number 4 - "Allow users to toggle the ability to yank their posts" clearly won (two most upvoted comments), yet wasn't implemented? 🤨

post.body:
Earlier today we posted [a big discussion thread](https://ruqq.us/5law) about the Yank mechanic. We had a lot of good discussion and ideas in that thread.

A lot of the underlying concerns fit into two categories: guildmaster abuse, and lack of communication.  Users were yanking content without regard to whether or not it fit, and Ruqqus itself did not notify users that their content had been yanked.

We've come up with a trial solution which we think will address these underlying concerns in a fair manner. We will try this for at least the next week, to see how well it works.

We've added a one hour cooldown on yanking. It works as follows:

* There is a one hour cooldown per-user
* There is also a one-hour cooldown per-guild
* Returning a post to its original guild (i.e. undoing a kick) ignores both cooldowns
* Yanking your own content also ignores both cooldowns.

Example: I am a guildmaster of +Ruqqus. I yank a random post from +general to +ruqqus. For one hour, I will be unable to yank anything to anywhere. For that same hour, no other guildmaster of +ruqqus will be able to yank content to +ruqqus either, but they will still be able to yank content to other guilds. 

With these cooldowns in place, we can also address the communication issue. We have added system notifications that are triggered by Yanking. We had left these out in the past since they could be used to spam with repeated kick-yank-kick-yank actions. Since that's no longer possible, we can add notifications without worrying about spam.

We hope that this addresses the underlying issues, while still allowing the Yank function to serve its original purpose of allowing unwanted content to find a new home.

As always, feedback is welcome below.
